questions.question: Every employee of your company has a Google account. Your operational team needs to manage a large number of instances on Compute Engine. Each member of this team needs only administrative access to the servers. Your security team wants to ensure that the deployment of credentials is operationally efficient and must be able to determine who accessed a given instance. What should you do?
options: Generate a new SSH key pair. Give the private key to each member of your team. Configure the public key in the metadata of each instance.
Ask each member of the team to generate a new SSH key pair and to send you their public key. Use a configuration management tool to deploy those keys on each instance.
Ask each member of the team to generate a new SSH key pair and to add the public key to their Google account. Grant the 'compute.osAdminLogin' role to the Google group corresponding to this team.

Generate a new SSH key pair. Give the private key to each member of your team. Configure the public key as a project-wide public SSH key in your Cloud Platform project and allow project-wide public SSH keys on each instance.
correctAnswer: Ask each member of the team to generate a new SSH key pair and to add the public key to their Google account. Grant the 'compute.osAdminLogin' role to the Google group corresponding to this team.
questions.hint: Think about security best practices, individual accountability, and OS Login features in Google Cloud.
questions.explanation:
### Key Concept
OS Login with IAM is Google Cloud's recommended way to manage SSH access to instances.

### Real-world Example
Imagine a company with 50 engineers needing server access:
- *Without OS Login*: Admin manually manages 50 SSH keys across hundreds of servers
- *With OS Login*: Engineers simply add their SSH key to their Google account, and admin assigns one IAM role

### Why it Works
- Each person uses their own key â†’ tracks who did what
- IAM role controls access â†’ easy to add/remove people
- Automatic user management â†’ no manual server updates

questions.question: You need to create a custom VPC with a single subnet. The subnet's range must be as large as possible. Which range should you use?
questions.hint: Consider the RFC1918 private IP address ranges and their network sizes
questions.explanation:
### Key Concept
When creating VPC subnets, you must use private IP ranges defined in RFC1918, with the size determined by the CIDR notation (/8, /12, /16 etc).

### Real-world Example
Comparing the available IP addresses in each range:
- 10.0.0.0/8: ~16.7 million addresses
- 172.16.0.0/12: ~1 million addresses
- 192.168.0.0/16: ~65,000 addresses

### Why 10.0.0.0/8 is Correct
- Largest private range available
- Safe for internal use - won't conflict with internet routing
- 0.0.0.0/0 is invalid as it represents all IPv4 addresses

ðŸ”— Learn more: [VPC Network Overview](https://cloud.google.com/vpc/docs/vpc)

questions.question: You want to select and configure a cost-effective solution for relational data on Google Cloud Platform. You are working with a small set of operational data in one geographic location. You need to support point-in-time recovery. What should you do?
options: Select Cloud SQL (MySQL). Verify that the enable binary logging option is selected.
Select Cloud SQL (MySQL). Select the create failover replicas option.
Select Cloud Spanner. Set up your instance with 2 nodes.
Select Cloud Spanner. Set up your instance as multi-regional.
correctAnswer: Select Cloud SQL (MySQL). Verify that the enable binary logging option is selected.
questions.hint: Consider cost-effectiveness and the minimum requirements for point-in-time recovery
questions.explanation:
### Key Concept
Point-in-time recovery in databases requires transaction logging, and the solution should match your data scale and budget.

### Real-world Example
Comparing costs for a small business database:
- Cloud SQL with binary logging: ~$50-100/month
- Cloud Spanner (minimum 2 nodes): ~$900/month

### Why Binary Logging is the Answer
- Enables point-in-time recovery at minimal cost
- Perfect for small datasets in single region
- Cloud Spanner would be overkill (designed for global, high-scale data)

ðŸ”— Learn more: [Cloud SQL Backup Options](https://cloud.google.com/sql/docs/mysql/backup-recovery/backups)

questions.question: You want to configure autohealing for network load balancing for a group of Compute Engine instances that run in multiple zones, using the fewest possible steps. options: Create an HTTP load balancer with a backend configuration that references an existing instance group. Set the health check to healthy (HTTP)

questions.question: You need to run an important query in BigQuery but expect it to return a lot of records. You want to find out how much it will cost to run the query. You are using on-demand pricing. What should you do?
options: Arrange to switch to Flat-Rate pricing for this query, then move back to on-demand.
Use the command line to run a dry run query to estimate the number of bytes read. Then convert that bytes estimate to dollars using the Pricing Calculator.
Use the command line to run a dry run query to estimate the number of bytes returned. Then convert that bytes estimate to dollars using the Pricing Calculator.
Run a select count (*) to get an idea of how many records your query will look through. Then convert that number of rows to dollars using the Pricing Calculator.
correctAnswer: Use the command line to run a dry run query to estimate the number of bytes read. Then convert that bytes estimate to dollars using the Pricing Calculator.
questions.hint: Consider how BigQuery pricing is calculated and which method provides accurate cost estimation without running the actual query
questions.explanation:
### Key Concept
BigQuery on-demand pricing is based on the amount of data processed (bytes read) during query execution, not the result size.

### Real-world Example
To estimate query cost:
1. Use dry run: bq query --dry_run 'SELECT * FROM dataset.table'
2. Get processed bytes estimate
3. Calculate cost: processed_bytes * $5/TB

### Why This Method Works
- Provides accurate cost estimate
- No actual query execution
- No charges incurred
- Based on actual pricing model
- Works for any query size

ðŸ”— Learn more: [BigQuery Pricing](https://cloud.google.com/bigquery/pricing)

### Why Use Cloud Function Events?
1. **Near Real-time Execution**:
   - Cloud Functions are triggered by events, ensuring timely compliance checks for changes in both Cloud Storage and Firestore.

2. **Minimal Setup**:
   - Cloud Functions are serverless, eliminating the need to manage infrastructure.
   - Native integration with Cloud Storage and Firestore events simplifies configuration.

3. **Compliance Use Case**:
   - For Cloud Storage, you can trigger the function on events like object creation, deletion, or metadata updates using `onFinalize` or `onMetadataUpdate` triggers.
   - For Firestore, you can trigger the function on document creation, updates, or deletion.

### Implementation Steps
1. **Create a Cloud Function for Cloud Storage**:
   ```bash
   gcloud functions deploy check-compliance-storage \
       --runtime python39 \
       --trigger-resource YOUR_BUCKET_NAME \
       --trigger-event google.storage.object.finalize
   ```
2. **Create a Cloud Function for Firestore**:
   ```bash
   gcloud functions deploy check-compliance-firestore \
       --runtime python39 \
       --trigger-event google.firestore.document.create \
       --trigger-resource "projects/YOUR_PROJECT/databases/(default)/documents/YOUR_COLLECTION/{documentId}"
   ```
3. **Add Security Script Logic**:

questions.question: Your application needs to process a significant rate of transactions. The rate of transactions exceeds the processing capabilities of a single virtual machine (VM). You want to spread transactions across multiple servers in real time and in the most cost-effective manner. What should you do?
options: Send transactions to BigQuery. On the VMs, poll for transactions that do not have the â€˜processedâ€™ key, and mark them â€˜processedâ€™ when done.
Set up Cloud SQL with a memory cache for speed. On your multiple servers, poll for transactions that do not have the â€˜processedâ€™ key, and mark them â€˜processedâ€™ when done.
Send transactions to Pub/Sub. Process them in VMs in a managed instance group.
Record transactions in Cloud Bigtable, and poll for new transactions from the VMs.
correctAnswer: Send transactions to Pub/Sub. Process them in VMs in a managed instance group.
questions.hint: Focus on real-time message distribution and scalable processing capabilities.
questions.explanation:
### Why Pub/Sub with Managed Instance Group?

1. **Pub/Sub for Real-time Message Distribution**:
   - Pub/Sub acts as a globally distributed message queue, capable of handling high throughput and large burst rates.
   - Automatically scales to handle increased transaction rates without additional setup.

2. **Managed Instance Group (MIG) Processing Power**:
   - MIG ensures scalability by automatically increasing or decreasing VM instances based on workload.
   - Distributes messages across multiple VMs in parallel using pull or push subscriptions from Pub/Sub.

3. **Cost Efficiency**:
   - You only pay for the messages processed and the computing resources used.
   - Avoids polling inefficiencies and unnecessary resource usage.

### Implementation Steps
1. **Setup Pub/Sub Topic and Subscription**:
   ```bash
   gcloud pubsub topics create transactions-topic
   gcloud pubsub subscriptions create transactions-sub \
       --topic=transactions-topic
   ```
2. **Create a Managed Instance Group**:
   - Use a startup script or application code within the VM template to pull and process messages from Pub/Sub:
   ```bash
   gcloud compute instance-templates create transaction-processor-template \
       --metadata=startup-script='python process_transactions.py'

   gcloud compute instance-groups managed create transaction-processors \
       --base-instance-name=transaction-processor \
       --template=transaction-processor-template \
       --size=3
   ```
3. **Code to Pull Messages from Pub/Sub**:
   Example Python logic:
   ```python
   from google.cloud import pubsub_v1

   def callback(message):
       print(f'Received message: {message.data}')
       # Process transaction here
       message.ack()

   subscriber = pubsub_v1.SubscriberClient()
   subscription_path = subscriber.subscription_path('your-project-id', 'transactions-sub')

   streaming_pull_future = subscriber.subscribe(subscription_path, callback=callback)
   try:
       streaming_pull_future.result()
   except KeyboardInterrupt:
       streaming_pull_future.cancel()
   ```

### Why Other Options Are Not Ideal
- **A: BigQuery**:
   - Heavy query costs and not suited for high-frequency real-time transactional processing.

- **B: Cloud SQL**:
   - Polling introduces delays and inefficiencies.
   - Scalability is more complex as Cloud SQL has limitations in terms of concurrent connections.

- **D: Cloud Bigtable**:
   - Designed for large analytical workloads, not real-time transaction polling.
   - Requires extra code for polling, introducing delays.

questions.question: Your team needs to directly connect your on-premises resources to several virtual machines inside a virtual private cloud (VPC). You want to provide your team with fast and secure access to the VMs with minimal maintenance and cost. What should you do?

questions.hint: Consider secure connectivity with minimal maintenance and lower costs.

2. **Low Cost**:

questions.question: You are implementing Cloud Storage for your organization. You need to follow your organizationâ€™s regulations. questions.question: You are creating a Cloud IOT application requiring data storage of up to 10 petabytes (PB). The application must support high-speed reads and writes of small pieces of data, but your data schema is simple. You want to use the most economical solution for data storage.

questions.question: You have created a Kubernetes deployment on Google Kubernetes Engine (GKE) that has a backend service. You also have pods that run the frontend service. You want to ensure that there is no interruption in communication between your frontend and backend service pods if they are moved or restarted. What should you do?
options: Create a service that groups your pods in the backend service, and tell your frontend pods to communicate through that service.
Create a DNS entry with a fixed IP address that the frontend service can use to reach the backend service.
Assign static internal IP addresses that the frontend service can use to reach the backend pods.
Assign static external IP addresses that the frontend service can use to reach the backend pods.
correctAnswer: Create a service that groups your pods in the backend service, and tell your frontend pods to communicate through that service.
questions.hint: Utilize Kubernetes' built-in service discovery mechanism.
questions.explanation:
### Why Create a Kubernetes Service?

Kubernetes Services provide a stable endpoint for communication between pods, even if those pods are moved or restarted. Here's why this is the best approach:

* **Abstraction and Service Discovery:** Services abstract away the dynamic nature of pod IPs, providing a consistent point of access for your frontend.
* **Load Balancing and Fault Tolerance:** Services distribute traffic across healthy backend pods, ensuring high availability.
* **Dynamic Updates:** As your backend scales or pods are rescheduled, the service automatically reflects these changes.

### Why Other Options Are Not Ideal:

* **DNS with Fixed IP:**  Pod IPs are dynamic, making fixed DNS entries unreliable.
* **Static Internal IPs:**  Kubernetes manages IP allocation; static assignments are not recommended.
* **Static External IPs:**  Exposing backend pods directly to the internet is a security risk and bypasses Kubernetes' networking model.

By using a Kubernetes Service, you leverage the platform's features for service discovery, load balancing, and fault tolerance, ensuring seamless communication between your frontend and backend.

questions.question: You are responsible for the user-management service for your global company. The service will add, update, delete, and list addresses. Each of these operations is implemented by a Docker container microservice. The processing load can vary from low to very high. You want to deploy the service on Google Cloud for scalability and minimal administration. What should you do?
options: Deploy your Docker containers into Cloud Run.
Start each Docker container as a managed instance group.

Combine the four microservices into one Docker image, and deploy it to the App Engine instance.
correctAnswer: Deploy your Docker containers into Cloud Run.
questions.hint: Focus on serverless solutions that abstract infrastructure management while enabling automatic scaling.
questions.explanation:
### Why Cloud Run is the Best Choice:

1. **Fully Serverless & Scalable:**
   - Cloud Run automatically scales from 0 to many instances based on incoming HTTP requests, handling variable workloads seamlessly.
   - No infrastructure management required (no nodes, clusters, or VMs to manage).

2. **Microservices Compatibility:**
   - Deploy each operation (add/update/delete/list) as independent services with separate containers, preserving modularity.
   - Cloud Run supports per-service scaling and versioning.

3. **Cost Efficiency:**
   - You only pay for the CPU and memory used during request processing.
   - Zero cost when no traffic (scale-to-zero capability).

4. **Simplified Operations:**
   - Automatic TLS, logging, monitoring, and CI/CD integration.

### Why Other Options Fail:

- **B: Managed Instance Groups (MIGs):**

- **C: Google Kubernetes Engine (GKE):**

- **D: Combining Services into One Image (App Engine):**
   - Defeats the purpose of microservices by coupling functionalities.
   - Limited flexibility for independent scaling and updates.

### Implementation Steps:

2. Deploy to Cloud Run with commands like:
   ```bash

       --image=gcr.io/PROJECT_ID/add-service \
   ```

3. Use concurrency settings and scaling parameters to fine-tune performance.

questions.question: Your team is building the development, test, and production environments for your project deployment in Google Cloud. correctAnswer: Use the Cloud Foundation Toolkit to create one deployment template that will work for all environments, and deploy with Terraform.
questions.hint: Leverage prebuilt deployment templates and parameterization to ensure consistency and efficiency.
questions.explanation:
### Why Use the Cloud Foundation Toolkit with Terraform?

1. **Prebuilt and Reusable Templates:**
   - The Cloud Foundation Toolkit provides modular and pretested Terraform templates, aligning with Google Cloud best practices for infrastructure deployment.
   - Templates cover common patterns, reducing development time and ensuring consistency across environments (e.g., development, test, production).

2. **Parameterization for Flexibility:**
   - You can efficiently customize templates using variables for environment-specific differences, such as machine types or network configurations.
   - Ensures uniform deployment processes while tailoring environments to specific needs.

3. **Enhanced Efficiency:**
   - Reduces complexity by avoiding starting from scratch.
   - Streamlines the process of deploying infrastructure repeatedly and consistently.

### Why Not the Other Options?

- **A: Cloud Shell Script with gcloud Commands:**
   - Hard to maintain and prone to human error; lacks reusability compared to Infrastructure-as-Code tools like Terraform.

- **B: Single Terraform Configuration with Parameterization:**
   - While this approach is valid, the Cloud Foundation Toolkit provides additional value by offering pretested modules consistent with Google Cloud practices, saving time and effort.

- **C: Separate Terraform Configurations for Each Environment:**
   - Manually managing multiple configurations results in duplication, inconsistency, and added maintenance effort.

### How to Implement:

1. **Use the Cloud Foundation Toolkit:**

     ```hcl
     module "vm_instance" {
       source       = "github.com/GoogleCloudPlatform/cloud-foundation-toolkit//modules/compute-vm"
       environment  = "${var.environment}"
       machine_type = var.machine_type
     }
     ```

3. **Deploy Environments:**
   - Use Terraform commands to deploy the consistent and flexible infrastructure:
     ```bash
     terraform init
     terraform apply -var environment=dev
     terraform apply -var environment=prod
     ```

questions.question: You receive an error message when you try to start a new VM: 'You have exhausted the IP range in your subnet.' You want to resolve the error with the least amount of effort. What should you do?

### Why Expanding the CIDR Range Solves the Problem:

questions.question: You are running several related applications on Compute Engine virtual machine (VM) instances. You want to follow Google-recommended practices and expose each application through a DNS name. What should you do?
options: Use the Compute Engine internal DNS service to assign DNS names to your VM instances, and make the names known to your users.

Use Cloud DNS to translate your domain names into your IP addresses.
correctAnswer: Use Cloud DNS to translate your domain names into your IP addresses.
questions.hint: Focus on external visibility and user-friendly domain name resolution for related applications.
questions.explanation:
### Why Use Cloud DNS to Expose Applications on VMs?

1. **Control and Flexibility**:
   - Cloud DNS allows you to create and manage custom DNS records for translating your domain names to the IP addresses of your VM instances.
   - Ideal for making your applications accessible with user-friendly names over the internet.

2. **Google-Recommended Practice**:
   - Cloud DNS is Google's fully managed DNS service, designed for consistent and reliable name resolution.
   - It's the standard for exposing applications with custom domain names.

3. **Public Accessibility**:
   - Internal DNS in Compute Engine is specific to instances within the same VPC and cannot be used for public DNS resolution.
   - Cloud DNS supports public DNS zones for external domains.

### Steps to Implement:
1. **Create a Public DNS Zone in Cloud DNS**:
   - Use the Google Cloud Console or CLI:
     ```bash
     gcloud dns managed-zones create my-zone \
         --dns-name="example.com." \
         --description="Public zone for my applications"
     ```
2. **Add DNS Records for Each Application:**
   - Map the application's IP address to a DNS name (e.g., `app1.example.com`).
     ```bash
     gcloud dns record-sets transaction start --zone=my-zone

     gcloud dns record-sets transaction add "INSTANCE_IP" \
         --name="app1.example.com." \
         --type=A \
         --ttl=300 \
         --zone=my-zone

     gcloud dns record-sets transaction execute --zone=my-zone
     ```
3. **Point Your Domain's Name Servers to Cloud DNS:**
   - Update your domain registrar's name server settings with the Cloud DNS name servers.

### Why Not the Other Options?
- **A: Internal DNS Service:**
   - Internal DNS works only within the VPC and isn't exposed to public users. It is not meant for external DNS resolution.
- **B: Alias IP Address Range:**
   - Alias IP addresses are better suited for load balancing or container deployments, not for DNS purposes.
- **C: Google Cloud Routes:**
   - Routes control network traffic and are unrelated to DNS or name resolution.

questions.question: You are charged with optimizing Google Cloud resource consumption. Specifically, you need to investigate the resource consumption charges and present a summary of your findings. You want to do it in the most efficient way possible. What should you do?

### Why Not the Other Options?

questions.question: You are creating an environment for researchers to run ad hoc SQL queries. The researchers work with large quantities of data. questions.question: You are migrating your workload from on-premises deployment to Google Kubernetes Engine (GKE). You want to minimize costs and stay within budget. What should you do?
options: Configure Autopilot in GKE to monitor node utilization and eliminate idle nodes.
Configure the needed capacity; the sustained use discount will make you stay within budget.
Scale individual nodes up and down with the Horizontal Pod Autoscaler.
Create several nodes using Compute Engine, add them to a managed instance group, and set the group to scale up and down depending on load.
correctAnswer: Configure Autopilot in GKE to monitor node utilization and eliminate idle nodes.
questions.hint: Look for a fully managed GKE solution that automatically optimizes resources to reduce costs.
questions.explanation:
### Why Configure GKE Autopilot?

1. **Fully Managed Cost Optimization:**
   - GKE Autopilot is a managed Kubernetes offering that automatically provisions and optimizes resources based on workload demands.
   - It eliminates costs associated with idle nodes by scaling down and only running workloads when necessary.

2. **Simplified Management:**
   - No need to manually configure or manage node pools.
   - GKE Autopilot eliminates the need to manage nodes, pods, or scaling policies directly, reducing administrative overhead.

3. **Pay-per-Use Pricing:**
   - Autopilot charges only for running workloads (CPU, memory, and disk resources actively used by pods).
   - Idle resources are scaled automatically, keeping costs low when the workload is light.

4. **Budget-Friendly:**
   - By dynamically managing resources based on utilization, Autopilot helps stay within budget.
   - Sustained use discounts apply without managing reserved capacity manually.

### Why Not the Other Options?

- **B: Sustained Use Discount with Fixed Capacity:**
   - Configuring fixed node capacity could lead to overprovisioning, resulting in wasted resources and higher costs.

- **C: Horizontal Pod Autoscaler (HPA):**
   - HPA manages only pod scaling, not node-level scaling (which requires a separate setup with cluster autoscaler).
   - Node management is still needed to prevent idle nodes.

- **D: Use Compute Engine Instance Groups:**
   - Compute Engine scales virtual machines, not containers. This approach requires additional engineering and management effort, making it inefficient for Kubernetes workloads.

### Implementation Steps:
1. **Create a GKE Autopilot Cluster:**
   ```bash
   gcloud container clusters create-auto my-cluster \
       --region=us-central1
   ```
2. **Deploy Your Workloads to the Cluster:**
   - Use `kubectl` to configure and deploy your workloads as usual.
3. **Monitor and Optimize Usage:**
   - Use Cloud Monitoring and Cloud Cost Management tools to track costs.

questions.question: You are creating a Google Kubernetes Engine (GKE) cluster with a cluster autoscaler feature enabled. You need to make sure that each node of the cluster will run a monitoring pod that sends container metrics to a third-party monitoring solution. What should you do?
options: Deploy the monitoring pod in a StatefulSet object.
Deploy the monitoring pod in a DaemonSet object.

Reference the monitoring pod in a cluster initializer at the GKE cluster creation time.
correctAnswer: Deploy the monitoring pod in a DaemonSet object.
questions.hint: Consider which Kubernetes object ensures a pod runs on every node in the cluster.
questions.explanation:
### Why Use a DaemonSet?

1. **Guaranteed Pod per Node:**
   - DaemonSet ensures that a copy of the pod runs on every node in the cluster
   - When new nodes are added by the autoscaler, DaemonSet automatically deploys monitoring pods
   - When nodes are removed, the DaemonSet pods are automatically cleaned up

2. **Perfect for Monitoring Use Case:**
   ```yaml
   apiVersion: apps/v1
   kind: DaemonSet
   metadata:
     name: monitoring-agent
     namespace: monitoring
   spec:
     selector:
       matchLabels:
         app: monitoring-agent
     template:
       metadata:
         labels:
           app: monitoring-agent
       spec:
         containers:
         - name: monitoring-agent
           image: monitoring-image:latest
   ```

### Why Not Other Options?

- **StatefulSet:**
   - Designed for stateful applications with unique network identifiers
   - Doesn't automatically ensure coverage across all nodes
   - More suitable for databases or other stateful workloads

- **Deployment:**
   - Manages replicated pods
   - Doesn't guarantee pod distribution across all nodes
   - Better for stateless applications

- **Cluster Initializer:**
   - Deprecated feature
   - Doesn't handle dynamic node additions/removals
   - Not suitable for ongoing monitoring needs

   ```yaml
   resources:

       cpu: 200m
       memory: 256Mi
     requests:
       cpu: 100m
       memory: 128Mi
   ```

   ```yaml
   affinity:

       requiredDuringSchedulingIgnoredDuringExecution:

   ```

questions.question: You've deployed a microservice called myapp1 to a Google Kubernetes Engine cluster using the YAML file specified below.
